segments.text: And this morning, we're going to have a very interesting and yet historical program as well.
Our guest for the talk show on Wednesday, March the 8th is Dr. Hugh M. Phillips, retired doctor of veterinary medicine.
And Dr. Phillips, how are you this morning?
Fine, Chipper.
We appreciate you coming out, and we're going to be talking about the history of veterinary medicine in Texas.
We're going to be talking about several things, as well as your career, not only here in Russ County, but before you moved to Russ County, which was back in the 40s, as I understand it.
But to get things rolling, tell us first of all, you've prepared a paper and it was presented a week or so ago in Longview at an East Texas historical meeting.
Tell us the purpose of the paper and why we're going into this history of veterinary medicine in Texas.
What's the purpose of it?
Well, Chipper, the first week that I retired in February of
1985, I went to Houston to the State Veterinary Convention and I was asked at that time if I would like to serve on the historical committee for the state association.
And since that was my cup of tea, I accepted that assignment and have enjoyed working with that group.
We meet twice a year.
Every August we meet in Austin and then
In the winter, we always attend the Texas Veterinary Medical Association convention and meet as a committee.
Okay, now, from this, you and other colleagues, veterinarians, are going to be compiling a book, I understand it.
That's right.
What's it going to entail?
Well, it will be entitled The History of Veterinary Medicine in Texas.
We thought that
At first we thought a catchy title might be proper, but we decided later that in the interest of communicating with people, we would call it The History of Veterinary Medicine in Texas.
That's not going to be quite a clinical book, I hope, one that anyone that could read and understand the terms and understand what went on just sort of a historical basis.
happening of how veterinary medicine got started in Texas?
It has to be more than just dates and pictures.
It will have some interesting stories in it and it will be readable.
If it isn't, then of course it won't sell.
And we want to sell books enough to pay for the printing.
When do you expect the book to be completed?
We have already hired an author last summer and he's working
Of course, it will probably still be another year or two.
Okay.
But the preliminary work has begun, and you, along with the other veterinarians of Texas, are doing research and talking and compiling this information, I guess, aren't you?
Right.
Well, let's just kind of get started.
Before we do, just a brief... We're going to be going into your...
that you've had here in Henderson.
You practiced, I believe, 38 years.
Yes, in Henderson.
In Henderson.
And before that, we'll be getting into your sort of biography in just a minute.
And we want to sort of get an idea of why veterinary medicine, when it began in Texas and why.
What started the interest in veterinary medicine?
The history of veterinary medicine in Texas...
is linked to the cattle industry and the Texas tick fever.
All of us who are old enough to remember seeing cattle die in the 1920 era know how important Texas tick fever was to the cattle industry.
The care and treatment of sick animals in Texas for many years were limited to the domestic livestock such as cattle, horses, mules, swine, sheep, and goats.
But
The main thing that people were interested in was the death of many cattle that were dying throughout the country with Texas tick fever.
Who diagnosed Texas tick fever?
Who gave it its name?
It was called Texas tick fever because it was supposed that the disease was caused by the ticks, but they weren't sure.
They had to prove it.
And of course...

As all of us older people remember, the Texas tick fever killed many cattle throughout the South, and the cattle that were on premises that were exposed in the northern states would die along the line of the trail drive as they went north.
Texas was very unpopular.
bringing their cattle into those other states.
I bet it was.
Okay, what years... Give us some dates when this began.
What are we talking about here?
We have recorded the fact that in 1855, the state of Missouri quit buying Texas cattle, boycotted Texas, you might say, because they had...
had learned that the cattle that came from Texas would kill some of their herds if they were exposed to the Texas cattle.
And that was before the Civil War in 1855.

So the seriousness of people boycotting Texas because of the Texas tick fever was reason enough to do something about this, because it was all the cattle in Texas and everything else, it was a big industry.
What, of course, right now, the Texas A&M Veterinary Medicine Center in College Station is very famous for the veterinary school there.
What brought it about?
Give us a little background on it.
How was Texas A&M Veterinary Medicine, how did you get it started?

In 1888, a combination of factors paved the way for the advent of a serious program in veterinary studies initiated at the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas, now known as Texas A&M University.
First, through the efforts of Dr. H. H. Dinwiddie, faculty chairman, the farmers and cattlemen around the state became aware of scientific breeding and care of livestock.
Also, the decade of the 1880s marked the crossroads for the Texas livestock industry.
A practical barbed wire invented by Joe Glidden of Illinois in 1873 began to have a great impact on Texas open range and the cattle industry.
The fencing wars of 1887 and 1888 are recorded in the history of ranching and farming in the Central and Southwestern states.
Then also influential to the development of veterinary medicine in Texas was the reluctance of the northern states to admit Texas cattle.
Some Texas cattle were immune to the disease by having it occur and surviving when they were young.
But northern cattle exposed to these Texas cattle produced epidemics which destroyed entire herds.
Of course, some of the cattle would live through the disease but became carriers, like people who had malaria could be carriers.
And those cattle, ticks would bite them and then go and bite healthy cattle in the northern states.
and they would start dying.
Okay.

Our guest this morning is Dr. Hugh M. Phillips, a retired doctor of veterinary medicine who has served 38 years here in the Henderson area as a veterinarian, and we're talking about the history of veterinary medicine in Texas, and we've got a very interesting program and a lot of information to give you, so stay tuned this morning.
We'll be back in just a moment.
on the Roadshow for a Wednesday morning, March the 8th, 1989.
Our guest, Dr. Hugh M. Phillips, retired doctor of veterinary medicine.

We're talking about the history of veterinary medicine in Texas, and a little later on, we're going to be talking more about his career, when he began study in veterinary medicine, his interest in veterinary medicine, and also
Some things he's run into here in Russ County over his 38-year career.
Sorry about that, doctor.
38-year career.
We're going to be throwing a lot of dates around at him.
Matter of fact, we started as early as 1855 when Missouri stopped importing Texas cattle.
And this came about because of Texas tick fever.
It's something that was spreading and was very...
deadly to the cattle in Texas and it was spreading and this did hurt the cattle industry in Texas.
Therefore, the veterinary medicine industry got a real close looking at.
And who were some of the early pioneers at Texas A&M University who came down and took a look at what was going on?
Where did they come from?
On June the 6th, 1888, Dr. Mark Francis became the first veterinarian
hired by Texas A&M, and through his work with cattle, became one of the most distinguished men in American veterinary history.
He was born in Ohio and graduated from Ohio State University in 1887 with degree of doctor of veterinary medicine.
Dr. Francis worked as associate professor of vet science and veterinarian for the newly created experiment station.
While Governor Lawrence Sullivan Ross was president of A&M College, the attitude of the public changed rapidly.
Governor Ross asked for a building for chemistry and one for veterinary medicine, but the legislature would not appropriate the money in spite of the plea of farmers and ranchers.
When Colonel L.L.
Foster became president of A&M after Governor Ross's death, he asked for a building costing $75,000, but returned from Austin and said he could get only $35,000.
The college accepted this $35,000 and built a two-story building.
The ground floor was used for veterinary medicine.
the second floor for chemistry.
This building stood where the Cushing Library now stands.
Dr. R.P.
Marsteller, who was dean of the vet school in 1940 when I was entered into the School of Veterinary Medicine, joined Dr. Francis in 1905 in the efforts to control tick fever.
He was also a graduate of the University of Ohio.
Governor James Pappy Ferguson

known well by all of the older people as Pappy, was impressed with the favorable results in immunizing cattle against Texas fever on his Bosque County ranch in February of 1916 and told the board of directors that he would approve an appropriation for suitable buildings for this purpose.
The next session of the legislature provided $100,000 for a building.
It was completed in 1918 through experiments in cooperation with Kansas Agricultural Experiment Station.
In 1894, the transmission of the Texas tick fever was narrowed down to the common southern tick, Buophilus bovis.
The discovery that the bite of this tick was the only way that Texas cattle fever was transmitted was the key
to the problem of how to control the disease.
Thus, by dipping all cattle with an arsenical dip, every two weeks the disease could be controlled.
Okay, so that was a very important finding then.
They found that they could control Texas tick fever by dipping cattle.
Describe dipping to us.
What is it?
Well, all of the people who are lucky enough to be 65 years old and older can remember
when all of our parents were dipping their cattle.
It was a big day when a little guy could go help drive the cattle to the dipping vats.
Of course, most of the older men who were dipping cattle then have already gone to their reward.
But we who are between 60 and 70 years old remember helping to dip the cattle.
In Gilmer, where I was born, I remember talking about it in the first grade, so that's why I know that it was in full swing in 1927.
And also, I've heard many people talk about the dipping vats in Russ County that they remember as children.
Did they completely submerge the cattle head and everything?
Yes, the cattle would be pinned behind the dipping vat.
They would have to be jumped off into the dipping vat.
Then they would swim about 12 to 15 feet and then be able to walk out.
And what was contained in the vat?
An arsenical mixture with the water of arsenic.
Okay, which when the ticks bit the cattle, the ticks died?
Yes.
Okay.
One question I would have, was Texas tick fever transferable to humans, from cattle to humans?
What happens when humans were bit by these ticks?
The Texas tick fever did not affect people other than killing their cattle.
It was a disease confined only to cattle caused by one species of tick.
very similar to the disease of malaria that was seen in people in that it was a protozoan parasite that was being transferred.
And this protozoan parasite lived in the red blood cells and destroyed the red blood cells, producing anemia and jaundice.
And one of the seriousnesses of this disease was that it was causing a loss of money to Texas.
I believe you have some facts and figures on how much it was costing us back then and the seriousness of it.
Give us a little history on that after they...
saw that there was a problem, they needed to find a cure.
But before that, I believe some studies were made, and how much money was Texas losing?
Way back in, I believe it was the early 1900s.

Well, despite the perfection of the dipping vats and inoculation of caves with blood from infected animals, which would give the young caves the disease, and most of them would live through it if they took the disease as a cave, and the caves were fed and properly treated, and that would immunize them.
In spite of this...
Dr. Francis reported in 1912 that losses from this disease in the United States still approached $50 million per year in deaths and restrictions of trade.
Texas tick fever was finally eradicated in the early 1930s by this compulsory dipping of all cattle every two to two and a half weeks during spring, summer, and fall.
But in 1911,

The biannual report by the government included a new reason for establishing the School of Veterinary Medicine at A&M, giving the number and the value of Texas domestic livestock as 16 million animals, valued at $350 million.
So with this much investment in the cattle industry here, we needed a ready supply of veterinarians, and there weren't that many veterinarians in Texas at that time, just under 100, as I understand.
That's right.
The care of all of these animals rested in the hands of only 75 out-of-state graduate veterinarians who were graduated in other states because Texas didn't have a veterinary school.
Several hundred untrained but certified practitioners

were also practicing a third group of self-styled veterinarians, usually referred to by most people as quacks, whose impossible remedies and irregular business methods had disgusted the public for years.
The state of Texas certified anyone who actively participated in the health care of domestic animals for five consecutive years preceding 1914.
I remember old Dr. Hare up at Gilmer, who was treating the cattle and the horses when I was a child.
And he was a certified non-graduate, moved from Winnsboro to Gilmer.
Okay, so where we're up to right about now is the 1914-1915 era, and we're just before A&M begins a veterinary medical school.
And we want to take a quick break right here and mention that Dr. Hugh M. Phillips is our guest this morning on the talk show.
He's a retired doctor of veterinary medicine and involved in a book being compiled now, The History of Veterinary Medicine in Texas.

And we're going to be talking more and at length about the history this morning and also his 38-year career here in Henderson as well and some of the particular and peculiar diseases that he's seen over the years here in Russ County and East Texas.
So stay with us this morning with Dr. Hugh M. Phillips, retired doctor of veterinary medicine.
We'll be back in just a moment.

Roadshow for Wednesday morning March the 8th 1989 our subject this morning is the history of veterinary medicine in Texas and we're going to be getting even more specific as that of here in Rusk County in just a few minutes but we're trying to lead you up and show you where veterinary medicine got started here in the state of Texas our guest is
38-year veteran here in Russ County of the veterinary profession, Dr. Hugh M. Phillips, retired doctor of veterinary medicine.
And he's our guest, and he's one of several men who are compiling the information for a book which will be entitled The History of Veterinary Medicine in Texas.
And let's see, Dr. Phillips, tell us about the founders of the College of Veterinary Medicine at A&M.
We're back in probably the early 1900s, around 1910 to 1915.
Give us some dates, and who were these people that started it?
Well, A&M had already hired Dr. Francis in 1888.
In 1911, Dr. R.C.
Dunn, another Ohio veterinarian, joined the A&M faculty as chief laboratory technician
in charge of the production of whole cholera serum.
That was another disease that was real important in Texas.
In 1913, the last of the four founders of the College of Veterinary Medicine at A&M joined the faculty.
Dr. Hubert Smith of Comfort, Texas, received his DVM degree from the Royal Veterinary College in Berlin, Germany in 1912.

and joined the staff at A&M working to control two other diseases which were called Creeps, C-R-E-E-P-S, and Loewen disease caused by mineral deficiencies and seen along the Texas Gulf Coast before minerals were added to the cattle feeding programs.
He was the fourth of the founders of veterinary medicine at Texas A&M.
During the decades after 1900, the veterinarians at A&M also worked extensively and successfully to control anthrax, black leg, tetanus, rabies, hoof and mouth disease, and hog cholera.
What year specifically was the College of Veterinary Medicine begun?
On April the 10th, 1916, the Board of Directors established the School of Veterinary Medicine at College Station.
Dr. Mark Francis was made the first dean.
Okay, and let's see, they started...
working on all these diseases that were common to Texas.
And what kind of facilities, what did they do to, what were their early buildings like?
How much money did they have to spend?
Did the state legislature come in with some money, or who provided the funding to begin the school?
I already mentioned the fact that they had secured money to build one building.
Right.
And, of course, in 1932,
the A&M directors decided to build a new vet hospital and clinic at the total cost of $225,000.
That's a lot of money in 1932, wasn't it?
Right.
And that money was derived from oil funds.
The East Texas oil boom was in swing, and a lot of money was going to Austin.
So they were able to build a few additional buildings in 1932 and 1933.
Those were the buildings that I used as a student.
They were over on the east side of the A&M campus.
But in 1953 and 55, a new and modern veterinary complex was erected west of the railroad on Farm Highway 60, costing millions of dollars.
The first class of graduates of the A&M Veterinary School was 13 in number, and they graduated in 19 and 20.

68 years ago dr raymond childers of jasper was the only one of those older men i personally knew he used to attend some of the conventions years ago he graduated 13 people in 1920 68 years ago my goodness and you met one of the original 13 and knew him okay um
Tell us about the years of the 20s and 30s for the veterinary.
They started graduating in 1920.
What was it like for a veterinary?
Well, during the 1920s and 1930s, a county in Texas was lucky to have a graduate veterinarian in the county.
And some counties didn't have graduate veterinarians until after World War II.
because many of the veterinarians volunteered and joined the armed services during World War II.
My hometown of Gilmer, Upshur County, was without a graduate practitioner until 1953 when Dr. Chester Studdard moved there from Tyler.
Well, let's get into a little bit about what interested you in veterinary medicine.
I guess as a child, you must have been interested in animals.
Tell us your story.
You said you grew up in Gilmer.
Tell us about that.
As a child, I was always interested in animals of any kind.
I had what my friends told me was a menagerie.
They didn't call it a zoo, but the backyard and cow pasture was full of animals.
I had goats.
and cattle and donkeys, rabbits and all kinds of pets, possums and whatever I could find to put in a cage and take care of.
And then also I helped to take care of all the neighbors' animals.
And I became a people person as well as an animal lover.
Don't give me any kind of work to do on mechanics, anything related to people or animals I'm interested in.
Of course, after that interest in animals, I went to A&M in 1938 thinking I wanted to become a county agent because I admired the county agent at Gilmer, Mr. W.D.
Seals.
I had never known a graduate veterinarian.
But after I became a student at A&M, looking at the textbooks of the vet students, I became interested.
And I was visiting my brother out in Rock Springs, Texas, Edwards County, and the county agent out there was doing the vet work.
My brother, being a young MD, would assist the county agent if it was some valuable animal.
So I was down there one Thanksgiving, and the two of them asked me why I didn't study veterinary medicine.
How old were you at that time?
Well, I had been in A&M a year and a half.
So I was possibly about 19 and a half years old.
So when I got back to A&M, I visited Dr. Marsteller in the dean's office and found out that I could easily change my course to veterinary medicine.
And that's the way I changed my mind and decided to be a veterinarian instead of a county agent.
I noticed in the notes that you had met Dr. Francis.
Now, he was the first licensed veterinarian that came to A&M in 1888.
Mark Francis, is that correct?
Right, Dr. Mark Francis.
Tell us that story when you got to meet him.
I believe you didn't know who he was when you met him until a couple of years later.
As a child, about 11 or 12 years old,
I was lucky enough that I got to go to A&M and spend a week when my father and the man who lived on my father's farm wanted to go and attend one of the short courses, a seminar.
The Chafin family lived on my father's old home place and two of their sons
and one of my brothers and I accompanied our fathers, and while they were attending the seminar, we could get out and roam the campus.
We were responsible children back in those days, and they didn't worry about us, so we visited all the buildings that were open.
One was a small museum, and in this museum,
They had the little lambs that were born with two heads and a little calf that had six legs and a colt that had two hoofs on each of its back legs.
Things like that I remember as though it happened yesterday.
And in this laboratory, or rather in this museum, was an old gentleman wearing a white coat and long white hair.
And I later learned, when I went to A&M, that he was Dr. Mark Francis, who had become interested in that museum.
And that was the year of probably 19...

30 or 31 that I met him there and spoke to him but had no idea who he was until I became a vet student in 1940 and I was told that Dr. Mark Francis was there in charge of that small museum the last few years that he lived.
He lived until 36 and I became a student at A&M in 38 and a vet student in 40.
Okay.
All right, tell us about when you entered vet school in 1940.
When did you graduate, and what did you do upon graduation?
In 1940, I became a student of veterinary medicine.
And, of course, World War II started in 1941.
And before I graduated, the ASTP,
ASTP, Army Specialized Training Program, started.

And about half of the senior class and most of the juniors and sophomores in the vet school were interested in Army careers, so they were taken to San Antonio and inducted into the Army and returned to A&M and finished their studies there.
And that was when Major Charles D. Apple, who resided here in Russ County for many years, became our commanding officer.
I met him at A&M, and then he was one of my very good friends when I started practicing here.
And many people know the Charles Apple family who lived out on the Kilgore Highway.
After graduating from A&M in October of 43,

six of us in the class received commissions as first lieutenants and then we went into the army left by train from dallas and arrived at carlisle barracks pennsylvania after about three days and went through this overseas training school at carlisle barracks that was the school at jim thorpe a famous
